content.description: Clip the first bolt of Jug-a-Lug and diagonal up and right for 5 more bolts through steep juggy patina to the anchors.
The crack right next to "No Is Hard To Say". Just another cruiser crack at The Crack House. A single 70 will get you back to the ground.
Fun moves, mostly big holds and not much jamming needed on the highly featured rock.
content.protection:
Gear to 2 1/2". Bolt anchors to right.

2 ropes recommended for the rappel.  It is possible to get down with a single 70 meter rope - just barely.  Use caution, tie knots in the ends of your rope.  Not possible with a single 60 meter rope.
content.location: The Crack House, on west side of the north corner of Castle Rock.   "No Is Hard to Say" is one of the most obvious lines at The Crack House, and is at the center of the wall at it's highest point.

climbs.name: No is a Four Letter Word (aka Ms. Alleneus)
climbs.fa: Rick Thompson, Jim Ghiselli, and Kevin Vowles: June, 1999

content.description:
A fun jaunt up very featured granite, with good protection through all but the first fifteen feet or so.

Start on a flat-ish spot below the large boulder on the slope at the base of the wall, and climb up through some hard-or-impossible-to-protect terrain. Eventually you'll reach a spot where a hand-size cam will fit (eg., #2 C4). From here go straight up through to a crack and from there to a small roof.

Head up the crack on the right side of the roof to a small overhang between two blocks, the left-most of which looks rounded and vaguely puffy. Surmount the steepness and head up the crack to the chain anchors.
content.protection: Cams #.5 to #4 C4 or equivalent, small through large nuts. Chain anchors.
content.location:
Located in approximately the middle of

Crack House

, starts below the large boulder on the slope, and ascends through the crack on the right side of the left-most pillow-looking block about three-fourths of the way up the wall.

content.description:
Great, juggy route.

Easy flare start leads to "OMG" holds all the way up, with a very short stretch of pure hand crack for a move or two.

Mostly a face climb with drop in pro nearly anywhere, and, a variety of sizes.

With a single 60m, rope, belay at the anchor then rappel, carefully, back down with the rope ends barely reaching the ground.

DO NOT LOWER OFF WITH A 60 METER ROPE!!!!  It won't reach.  Tie a knot in the belay end or have both people tie in.
content.protection: No fixed gear.  Standard rack works great.  Could use up to a 4 camalot but there's many opportunities for different sizes of pro.
content.location:
First route to the left of Jug-a-Lug.

Climb up then left to the anchor on Dark Rock, Good Rock.

content.description: A fun overhung route on a highly featured face.  The crux is at the end of the steep section just before the route slabs out at the finish.
content.location: Upper (right) end of the Crack House, west side of the north corner of Castle Rock.

content.description: Continue on after the belay bolts on Gargoyle Gardens. Lowers with a 70 meter rope.

Climb up the vertical features and than traverse left when you are 20ft or so underneath the anchors. Lots of awesome feet that allow you to either find protection or rest.  An alright climb to get warmed up for The Crack House.
content.protection: Standard rack will stitch this up (probably excessive especially with bolted anchor)
content.location: Look for the low set of anchors roughly 10-15ft from the north edge of The Crack House wall.  This route shares an anchor with Bold Yellow (a 5.10)

content.description: A fun little crack with a crux overhang. Fun moves
content.protection: standard rack plus some extra small stuff.  Bolted anchor and two bolts by overhang
content.location: Look for the obvious overhang down low. Its covered in lichen
